George Harrison played two different versions of this solo: the first version was recorded in early 1969 for the single version of this song, while the solo for the final album version was recorded in January 1970.

The original recordings, as featured in the eponymous Let It Be movie and later Anthology, had a third variation: “There will be no sorrow, let it be”.

And when the night is cloudy, there is still a light that shines on me

When Paul’s intuition is cloudy, his mother (Mary), who passed away, helps guide her son – illuminates his path if you will.

The “night is cloudy” bit could also be referring to the internal tension and conflict developing within the band at the time of recording. Such unpleasant times could be described as a “cloudy night” as a pseudonym for dark times.

And in my hour of darkness, she is standing right in front of me
 Speaking words of wisdom, “Let it be”

When Paul’s down and out, he just pictures his momma telling him to relax. After she passed Paul didn’t know what to do and he had a dream (hence hour of darkness, while he’s sleeping) and his mom came to him and told him to let it be.

The hour of darkness has a double meaning… While he’s sleeping literally yes but figuratively when he’s going through dark times

When I find myself in times of trouble, Mother Mary comes to me
 Speaking words of wisdom, “Let it be”

Mother Mary is not the Virgin Mary (although Paul was obviously aware that most listeners would take it that way), but Paul’s actual mother who died when he was young.



Paul said he wrote this after a dream he had where his mother came to him and said, “let it be.”
